newsitem.title: USA: Procter & Gamble net aided by favorable prices.
newsitem.headline: Procter & Gamble net aided by favorable prices.

text.p: Consumer products giant Procter & Gamble Co. Tuesday reported higher quarterly profits and cited favourable commodity prices for raw materials and cost cutting.

The company, whose products include Tide detergent and Crest toothpaste, said its profits rose to $944 million, or $1.35 a share, on revenues of $9.14 billion in its fiscal second quarter ended Dec. 31. A year earlier it earned $836 million, or $1.18 a share, on revenues of $9.09 billion.
"Although improved from last quarter, our priority remains to accelerate sales and unit volume growth," Chief Executive John Pepper said in a statement.

Procter & Gamble said it expected growth to come through areas such as new product initiatives and added production capacity. The Cincinnati-based company's other products include Ivory soap, Prell shampoo, Noxzema skin cream and Cover Girl cosmetics.
Worldwide unit volume was a record, growing 2 percent from the year-ago quarter, P&G said.
Sales for the quarter grew 1 percent to $9.14 billion, P&G said, adding the difference between sales and unit volume growth was largely due to weaker currencies in Europe and Asia.
For the six months, worldwide volume was up 2 percent over the year-ago period while sales were stable, primarily reflecting unfavourable exchange rates.
Cost reduction efforts and lower commodity prices, especially pulp, also helped earnings for the six months, P&G said.
For the six months, earnings rose to $1.92 billion, or $2.74 a share, on revenues of $18.04 billion. A year earlier it earned $1.73 billion, or $2.45 a share, on revenues of $18.12 billion.
P&G stock was up $6.125 to $113.875 in afternoon trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
